content_standard: Students analyze the global political and social structures of the premodern world (ca. 1750) that precede the age of democratic and industrial revolutions.
overview: Students begin tenth-grade world history with a survey of the world in 1750, analyzing maps of the major empires, trade routes, and colonies. This period is characterized as the **very end of the premodern world**. The unit sets the stage for the dramatic transition from divine monarchy to the modern nation-state organized around Enlightenment principles.

questions: How were most societies organized in the 1700s?
Who held power in the 1700s? Why?
What was the divine right of kings?

content_and_themes.theme: I. Political Structures: Monarchy and Dynastic Rule
details: Most states and empires in 1750 were ruled by a **single leader**, who might be called a king, tsar, sultan, emperor, shah, or prince.
The ruler usually came from a **dynasty** (a family of rulers).
Rulers secured their legitimacy from **birth** into the royal family and the subsequent support of **religious and political elites**.
Most emperors claimed they had been **chosen or blessed by divine power** and ruled on behalf of God to maintain order and justice in the society.
Dynasties and elite groups protected their power, wealth, and privileges through customs of social order, force, and propaganda.
They usually **resisted giving power** to lower social groups, fearing they would lose their wealth and privileges.

Students analyze maps of the **gunpowder empires** (Qing China, Mughal India, Ottoman Empire, Safavid Persia, Spain, France, England), trade routes (Atlantic World, Pacific/Indian Ocean, and world trade systems), and colonies.
Customs of social order across all societies were **hierarchical**, meaning people were generally unequal.
